awd_abstract_narration:
The most familiar products of modern astronomy research are the breathtaking images produced by several spectacular, ambitious, and often general-purpose space-based satellite missions that have reshaped our view of the Universe.  Equally important to actually understanding the workings of specific objects is the laborious, detailed study using ever-improved instrumentation on ground-based optical telescopes.  Spectroscopic studies, comparing light output from astrophysical sources at different wavelengths, and recognizing the characteristic patterns emitted by specific atoms and molecules that emit in the same way as those components do here on Earth, is particularly powerful.  The investigators on this project aim to build a sensitive instrument dedicated to observations of one particular spectral transition that is key to a number of interesting puzzles facing modern astrophysical research, including the behavior of the material that is seen to form a halo around distant galaxies.

The spectral line targeted by the instrument being built is the H-alpha line, and the instrument takes its name from that line and the principal science interest, galactic halos:  CHaS, the Circumgalactic H-alpha Spectrograph.  Kinematics of gas in the circumgalactic medium of galaxies in the nearby universe will measure the distribution of infalling and outflowing gas within the central 50-100 kpc of a galaxy's halo, and will establish a new technique for testing the modes of accretion and outflow in galaxies across cosmic time.

This project will contribute solidly to the training of the next generation of instrumentation scientists.  A novel approach to outreach will also be explored:  making simplified versions of the Integral Field Unit available to amateur astronomers, exploiting and building upon a long-standing synergy between amateur and professional astronomers.

Funding for this project is being provided by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

por.por_cntn:
An important outcome of astronomical research is the determination of the amount, distribution and movement of atoms in the Universe.  Such a census of atoms can be used to understand the physical processes that underlie the formation and evolution of the many astronomical objects that we see?notably galaxies, which contain many billions of stars?and the large-scale structures in which they are found.  Observations suggest that these objects and structures also harbor massive amounts of dark matter, whose nature has yet to be fully understood.

For this project, we have developed a powerful new instrument specifically designed to advance our census of the atomic Universe, by detecting and mapping the motions of the massive reservoirs of gas predicted to surround galaxies. This so-called "circumgalactic" gas may contain a significant fraction of the atoms in the Universe. Its study can provide important insights into the manner by which gas flows into and out of galaxies, the formation and evolution of stars and black holes, and the distribution and properties of dark matter.

This novel instrument, the Circumgalactic H-alpha Spectrograph (CHaS), is optimized to obtain the deepest-ever maps of the circumgalactic medium of galaxies in the nearby Universe.  CHaS has been built and has undergone early commissioning on the MDM (Michigan-Dartmouth-MIT) Telescope on Kitt Peak in Arizona. Its wide field of view, field-slicing optics, and overall design properties, allow it to obtain 60,000-240,000 simultaneous spectra across circumgalactic regions, with a velocity resolution of 20-40 km/s.  The excellent velocity resolution of CHaS is needed for the detailed study of the gas flows around galaxies.  Importantly, its velocity resolution, narrow bandpass, and efficient design also allow CHaS to be sensitive enough to map the tenuous circumgalactic gas, with signal levels that have thus far eluded detection.  

CHaS was initially proposed to only study emission from redshifted hydrogen near 656 nm. During the early stages of the project, the CHaS design was modified to allow its detection band to be centered within a wide, 480-920 nm spectral range, enabling studies of a rich assortment of diagnostic emission lines from extremely faint and diffuse astrophysical objects.  Other changes included the incorporation of a volume phase holographic grating and the use of new commercial off-the-shelf optics. These modifications improve performance and add flexibility in implementation and observation.

The CHaS instrument was first commissioned at MDM in winter 2020.  Shortly thereafter, the COVID-19 pandemic shut down Kitt Peak and the MDM telescope. In fall 2020, CHaS was returned to Columbia University for additional testing and refinement.  Once Columbia University travel restrictions were lifted in May 2021, CHaS was returned to MDM for installation and a longer period of early commissioning, much of which occurred in the second half of 2021.  Early observing targets have included several nearby galaxies and Galactic nebulae.  Analysis of spectral images, performed with a custom-built data pipeline, indicate that the completed instrument is performing as planned, with new discoveries made possible given its capabilities.  Continued commissioning and science observations are planned starting in 2022-2023 and new scientific results are expected to be reported soon thereafter.

Graduate students, undergraduates and young scientific staff members have had a significant role throughout the CHaS development effort.  The graduate student that led the project from the design phase through commissioning, successfully completed her thesis in 2021.  Over the duration of the project, five other graduate students and eleven undergraduates have performed engineering, construction, testing, and analysis required for the project. Notably, several key team members are from traditionally underrepresented groups in astronomy.  

The CHaS project has also included the development of an educational version of the instrument, MicroCHaS, designed to be deployed at schools and other sites for broader impact. The team effort has mainly focused on several design iterations of MicroCHaS, tested on the telescope in the Rutherfurd Observatory atop Columbia's Pupin Hall.  The plan remains to distribute versions of this instrument, together with supporting software and training, in the coming years.  Both CHaS and MicroCHaS have also being integrated into the curriculum of several observing courses and have been used as a model for several space-based mission concepts.

Although many of the technologies behind CHaS are relatively mature, the combination of these subcomponents has resulted in an instrument that occupies a unique parameter space among astronomical spectrographs, making it a prototype for future explorations. Additionally, CHaS design and the analysis algorithms required to interpret its data have broad relevance to instruments and software developed for solar physics and multispectral remote sensing.
